Out the door they were some of my favorite mixes I've ever done and Heba brought something else to them that I couldn't or wouldn't have thought to. I trust her taste & I asked for her imprint. I think there's a way to do both... you can 100% encourage a mastering engineer to push things further and forward without undercooking a mix... but it definitely requires an alignment of taste and trust.

author: cian riordan
content: Ruairi fishing for deep cuts! The best experience I ever had was over a decade ago. Having spent a considerable chunk of time recording an album for & with my best friend -- we asked Eric Valentine to master the record and he said yes. Having worked under for him for a few years at this point, it felt like a bit of a reckoning... having him critically listen to something I had really poured my all into. Needless to say, he treated it as he treated everything... with genuine curiosity and actionability. He sized up the mixes in no time, told me the strengths, the weaknesses, even sent me into the other room to re-print versions slightly quieter, fix this pop here, maybe put the guitar solo up here. He gave it his full 12 hours (what felt like 100 hours to me) and the end product leveled up in so many ways. Granted he is not really a 'mastering engineer', but he approached this little project like he approached everything in his music career, with a deep sense of giving a fuck and knowing that there's no real excuse to not fix the obvious issues in front of you. The album sounded fantastic and it really spoiled me for what a mastering experience could be.

author: chrissorem
content: I’ve been mastering a lot more of my own mixes recently. Mostly because I’m mixing into a mastering chain and generally doing very small moves. So my approach has been to take all my mixes and bypass the limiter and  load the sequence up. I’ll also have my limited mixes below my unlimited mixes in this session. Most the work I’m doing is light rx work and a touch of eq but mostly trying various limiters and limiter settings to see if I can beat what I did in the mix. The real advantage of mastering my own mixes is that once I move heard them in the final sequence I’ll sometimes adjust minor things in the mix. Maybe vocal up or bass down ect.. rather than trying to solve this with 2bus processing. The down side of me mastering is not getting a trusted second perspective

content: Early days. I had printed then sent an album on its way to vinyl without listening through it first. author: masteredbyjack
content:
Yes -- definitely save as montage every single time I ship a file, and then before I do any adjusting on a revision. So previous pass is kept as is.

It depends on how I name it. Like you said, any system that makes sense to you and is granular enough to track all files shipped will work. These days, with albums very often coming in slow dripped as singles, and massive amounts of changes last minute (it's how the game is), it pays to be very organized. I'll even go so far as to name things descriptively if it makes sense for the project (brighter, heavier, etc etc), or by date, whatever. 

But the real work of mastering every day is very messy, and you have to have a good way to track everything.

Granted, I'm more of a "creative" type from my experience than a very in the weeds structured type (neither right or wrong), so my system works for me. I can always get exactly back to what was shipped, montage open within under a minute for sure which helps creative flow.

My 2 cents -- I'd totally do away with the initial rough master. Think of it from the client side. Rough master says "hey give me validation" and puts the onus on them to listen. Every interaction incurs a cost. Sending just the master, exactly as you hear it and owning it, works so much better in my experience (believe me, I've been the guy to send options before back in the day). Ruairi is exactly right on this

author: chrissorem
content: I too always open a new session for mastering and sequencing. Even if I’m not mastering I do this. Once there is a sequence it’s not uncommon for me  to go back and tweak a mix or two. Generally small moves like bass up or down a db, vocals up or down.  And I like to try and get the ins and outs worked out with the artist even if I’m not mastering. This allows for less back and forths with mastering and allows them to spend their time on more important moves. If I know I’m mastering my own mixes from the get go. I tend to leave a db of head room on my final limiter because people expect louder. And then when I master I put that db back

author: Railtown Mastering
content:
100% get that spark of excitement. Bit different than the lightning in a bottle thing that can happen when you’re sitting in the room, but it still scratches the itch for me. Definitely have moments where I’m like, man, I can’t believe I get to be a part of this.

I came from a background in recording and mixing, which really helped when I transitioned into mastering. I never actively promoted all three since my goal was always to master full-time, but for a while, I did a bit of everything with existing clients to make ends meet. Now, I’m lucky to be so busy with mastering that I don’t even have time to consider other work. And while I could probably still pull off a passable mix, my friends who do it every day would do a much better job. I think there’s immense value in eventually specializing and putting all your energy into one place.

Having said that, everyone’s path looks different, and there’s no single right way to get where you want to go. For me, specializing and putting all my energy into mastering was the right move, but I know plenty of people who thrive wearing multiple hats. I think the key is figuring out what excites you most and what you’re best at, and leaning into that.

author: eschirtz
content:
I hear you Ruairi, and ultimately you gotta make your own call on this. 

But I just wanna reassure you that our business is built around serving your type of workflow. Even if 99% of users don't give a shit about the perfect playback, we do. That's why we have that "lossless" switch. We'll never switch to AAC due to bandwidth issues.

The "constant upgrades" are often due to the ever changing landscape of browsers. Each client is often on a different browser, different device and different internet connection. It's our job to understand that landscape and push fixes to ensure we get perfect playback across all environments. 

That's part of the reason we built the iOS app, to be able to provide a more consistent playback experience when browsers themselves are the limiting factor, and so that clients can listen offline to take the network out of the equation. But I totally understand that you can't really ask a client to install another app on their iPhone. 

To my knowledge, Samply is still the only platform that lets clients stream full resolution lossless AND gapless track transitions in a browser. It's a really tough engineering challenge, but ultimately the backbone of our entire business. We're committed to continuing to solve this problem and evolve with the technology available.

author: masteredbyjack
content:
Bigger question I think we want to help @danrobinson30 with -- what's actually useful in a DAW for mastering. Of course you can use any and all. From my view:

1. Clip based processing + automation
2. Ability to handle markers/delinate what regions and where to render audio quickly and easily. And within album contexts (say we just want to adjust one song, is it easy).
3. Ability to handle various transition types/seamless
4. Ability to easily render ALTS or replace mixes (moving settings from one clip to another)
5. File management, ease of setting up render paths, etc

Definitely more to it of course for complicated projects

author: masteredbyjack
content:
Keep in mind I’m still very new to mastering compared to most here, but this has happened several times already to me.

I’d do it on goodwill. Ideally your workflow and back end systems would make this a very small lift. Unless it’s something wild, better to have the client have a wonderful experience, keep their momentum, don’t introduce doubt, double down on their confidence, etc.

I’m assuming it would be something like making sure the levels and overall tone are right if you’ve already mastered them all and they are in the same ballpark, but feel free to tell me if I’m wrong.

Also “cohesion” is massively overrated to me anyway, I much prefer a creatively interesting and varied listening experience if the music calls for it as long as we are not having wild level or EQ swings or something (sometimes it calls for cohesion to have the best listening experience IMO, so know that too!). 

I’ve had multiple instances where an artist’s new “single” release includes their several past singles I’ve mastered too. They didn’t tell me they were doing that, and I mastered each totally alone, just based on the song and their vision. And to be honest those collections sounded totally fine every time as a group of singles, mastered alone.

All that said, I’d definitely politely educate them on what it exactly entails so it doesn’t happen again in future, and so they can take it into account creatively.

But of course where you are in your career, the relationship with this client, etc all plays into this. Someone like @Nomograph Mastering could very well see this very differently than me

author: Zach Hughes
content:
A few thoughts on all this.. I agree with @Nomograph Mastering that the top of funnel for Spotify isn't bringing in enough money to overnight increase the amount music rights holders are paid. However, I am not convinced Spotify couldn't raise their subscription price in certain markets. Netflix has successfully raised their prices many times over the years. I've been paying the same price for Spotify for close to 10 years (maybe it increased a dollar at one point, but not sure).

I do believe Daniel Ek and Spotify have earned some ire from the music community. Ek is a billionaire and the average Spotify employee makes close to $110k / year. You would probably need around ~1.5 million monthly listeners and ~3.5 million streams / month to earn an equivalent amount (master recording side sans publishing and no other income stream). There are maybe a little over 6000 artists that have that large of a listenership in the entire world out of conservatively 5-7 million artists on the platform.

There are many things Spotify could do to improve economic outcomes for artists / musicians. Here are a few in no particular order:
1) Allow artists to link to their own website. Believe it or not we can't do this. Your own website is the one piece of online real estate that you actually control. On Spotify, IG, Tiktok, etc... you are playing in someone else's sandbox.
2) Allow artists more control over their profiles and the way they are laid out. One thing that infuriates me is how Spotify sorts albums by popularity rather than release date. I would like to change that. This would be beneficial to promoting newer releases. As well all external links off of Spotify are virtually hidden on the 'about' page at the bottom of your profile making it harder for fans to follow you where you want to be followed.

author: Edsel Holden
content:
Any “material change” to the musical content means it’s a new recording for ISRC assignment

In their published FAQ, IFPI gives examples of modifications that do require a new ISRC, including: remixes or edits to the recording, and changes in playing time exceeding 10 seconds - SOURCE

Extended intros/outros or cross-faded transitions fall under these categories when they alter the length or content of the track in a noticeable way. The U.S. ISRC agency (RIAA) offers similar rules: “A new ISRC must be issued when: a sound recording is re-mixed or edited; if a new fade changes the length of a track by more than 10 seconds; [or] edits change the length of a recording by more than 10 seconds.” - SOURCE

author: Rob Domos
content:
Trying not to get wrapped up stories that keep me from hearing what’s in front of me. There’s plenty of potential for those stories. 

Music is brilliant to me, like 808 music on opioids, and a teenager engineer made it significantly leaner than pale waves (in more than one song 9k is 10db louder than 2k) and sent it to distro with true peak all the way down at -3.

The artist is like a little brother to me, is 10/10 serious about being a full time artist, and I think the music itself deserves an editorial playlist spot (he’s landed 2 before!) but the sonics on this album are prohibitive so I’m trying to quickly do a master swap for him. 

There’s no way for this to sound fully traditional (and I’m not sure we’d want it to). It will be punk, it will be weird. The goal now is for the quirks to be a portal into a new experience rather than a barrier between the artist and the listener. Very delicate to navigate

content: Nothing’s gonna stop people from wanting to spend their time doing cool and challenging stuff. Some creators will use every AI tool available, and some will skip it all. Kids drive music culture and kids lean nostalgic. There are more garage bands than ever now and young people listen to the cure. AI tools will help kids make the albums they want without asking mom and dad for thousands to get it mixed/mastered, but it won’t stop peoples desire to learn how to do stuff, and it won’t stop the need for real human guidance and mentorship. Our job as producers mixers and masters is to shepherd music into a state that aligns with our perceived level of quality based on many years of hearing and making music. We won’t be out of a job, but who knows what tools we’ll be  using

author: Øra Mastering
content: I work both hybrid and itb. When working hybrid, I try to keep the same settings for a whole album and do eq, de-essing and level automation pre analog if needed (on individual tracks). On some albums, for me, there is no way around tweaking analog settings per track, but I try to avoid it. When printing the album I use the print-time to casually listen to the album from start to finish to catch stuff I would like to adjust (one track lacks impact ect.). Final limiter is always post analog print and I do not print hot. This makes revisions a breeze 97% of the time, unless there is a new mix of course. Also easy to back of a limiter without reprinting if the client wants more dynamics or I want a more dynamic vinyl pre-master. Hope that made sense.

author: spectrummasters
content:
...so, the short answer jack is yes , the wide q eq moves are definitely advantageous and applicable outside of the mastering stage (for my workflow)....very much so. I think in a way , the broad eq is sort of like a painter taking a few steps back from the canvas having been working up close on a detailed brushstroke (which I’d suggest for example is like a surgical eq move in a mix or saturating a sound at the production stage etc).....”stepping back” and listening not just to The minutiae but the overall tone i think is a discipline that is potentially easy to forget in mix mode ......and in a sense this is how the broad EQ is serving me . I find the eq points ruairi shared work v well at the group bus stage also......for light touches

With regards to whether I’m only mastering . No, currently my most common paid work comes from local / independent artists in my network I’ve built mostly from my local community outwards through word of mouth. This is primarily in the rnb/trap/hip-hop genres and for better or worse it appears to have been normalised that when someone wants a mix....what they want is a mixter. I’m with Derek Ali’s Enginears platform and even there they are promoting a free master from us as mixers on the platform.
Personally, I’m not against certain mixers mastering as well....but i think this is more genre specific.....and also v much down to the individual. I think you spoke about your arc on here into mastering and others have too. ....i believe there is much to benefit from having professional mastering engineers, with thousands of hours under their belt listening to thousands of tracks in excellent environments......take the final listen and make the final adjustments on a mix..and for me, i consider myself on a career arc towards becoming that .

author: Edsel Holden
content:
Hello Brodie. I have had plenty of times where singles are drip fed to me over the course of weeks or months and then ultimately they all land on an EP or album together. I try to ask a lot of questions on the front side about plans and sequence and try to listen to the whole project (even if in prog) and just use that knowledge to make sure everything stays consistent. It’s not uncommon for me to have a little note in a montage about what general level I mastered the previous singles to so that I have that info on hand and can ensure things are close enough. If the songs are recorded by the same person, mixed by the same person, and they all come my way for mastering - I usually don’t have a problem keeping things consistent enough over the course of a few weeks. Hopefully that’s helpful ! 

Also want to add the goal is not every song same level. Just keeping in mind how the project will flow overall and having that info in front of me I find helpful sometimes when a lot of time has passed.

author: Iwan Morgan
content:
Interesting response by Chris Gehringer in the new MWTM Q+A section: 

*"Dereck, You really hit home with this one.
I’m 99% ITB for over 10 years was well. I was more hybrid earlier on during my conversion period and now mostly all in due to my workflow and client time demands.

I definitely feel like i’m chasing Refs with the same plugins used by mixers and producers sometimes and don’t feel creative but that’s the game lately. I really feel this is the main problem. I’m not really happy when i’m pushed in that direction.
With almost everyone having the same plugins it’s very apparent that most masters in a shootout sound the same now. No surprises there.

Is Analog Better?

I recently bought a Terry Audio CEQ to try and change my sound and it definitely works. It has an amazing sound and color that cannot be found in most plugins. That being said it doesn’t work for me all the time.
Many of the projects i work on are so loud and pushed anything run through analog gear loses the “glue” that is in the digital mix.
I also just got a Sontec MES-432D9D from Make Believe Studios.
It actually sounds like the real thing to me. It has a much different vibe when using it. I find myself using different frequencies from other EQs.
Is That Better? I’m not sure yet but getting good results when i use both of these tools.

I think the most important part of my setup is that I’m very familiar with my plugins and know when to use different ones when necessary (its also so easier to try another one if you’re not sure obviously)
I’m constantly trying to stay fresh and not mail it in.

Not sure if there’s an actual answer for this but i hope i answered some of your question or at least validated our situation.

Chris"*

author: jordanmcleod_io
content: I'm no where as experienced as some of the other peeps in here, but have some thoughts. I think you kind of answered your own questions. $10 is crazy low and not sustainable for anyone, I'm not sure what that other engineer could actually be doing besides blasting tracks through Ozone. Since you are already cold emailing, I think your time could be better sent searching out artists who are in need of an ME and get your full rate there. If you took the $10/gigs, they would eventually be dropped anyways as more full rate gigs started coming in. If it were me, I would rather work the word of mouth game through the artists you are DMing and hopefully more gigs stream in that way via other artists, producers, or mixers. Put in the work now creating meaningful relationships and connections that can exponentially grow instead of the label path which seems like a dead end. I've been cold DMing artists with a freebie first song, I just started this month and it's a big numbers game, so I can't say for certain how it will go. But, because of the freebie I gave them, I am now talking with these different artists about mastering an album, an EP, and several singles at full rate. This is rhetorical, but how many cheap label songs would you need to master in order to get the same amount of money? So in short, if it were me, I would spend my time elsewhere creating more meaningful relationships with much more room to grow.

author: Val ᶠʳ
content:
Here are my scripts to generate PQ sheets for CDs and Vinyls : 
It's very customized for the workflow I've described, and it's made with ChatGPT and dirty personal tweaks so I can't guarantee it will work smoothly everywhere.
For vinyl, the script is looking for regions in the project in order to define the different "Sides" of the vinyl, and then markers for songs timing references, ISRCs etc.
So I add regions in the session, named : "Side A", "Side B" etc. and export them as .wav, alongside the Cue Sheet.

author: Rollmottle
content:
I don’t have the volume of work some others here do so I am more likely to have the time others don’t have to send something to outboard. With that said, I am digital 95% of the time. On the rare occasion I use my outboard, it will more than likely be a single. I will always capture the print pre-limiter. And if I need to tweak something, it will be done with a digital EQ.

These days, I’d never do an album where all the tracks go out. It takes too much time to document, extra time to capture, and when the inevitable mix swap comes, extra time to recall, reprint etc. I used to, but it doesn’t scale well if you have any meaningful volume of work where recalls or in flight projects become prohibitive to you handling more than one work stream for multiple clients at once.

author: popthetrunk
content:
I don’t do this a ton, but my workflow is similar to those described above, but with brush tool and quick key based. 

In Automator: 
Create a workflow

Get specified Finder items(this is where you swap the file)
Open Finder Items(application: iZotope RX x.x)
Watch me do(record button)
Iist of actions ends up looking like: Mouse Clicked, Press apple + 6, Mouse clicked, Press apple + 2, etc.
If I do a selection from the right click drop-down I used the arrow keys and enter for selection.
Then end Automator recording after that type of editing before doing anything else I would normally do with rx. This is obviously clunky compared to the basic timecode relative media swapping in pt or layers in after effects but it does work okayish

author: masteredbyjack
content:
Ruairi, to both you and @Gerhard Westphalen …I find both of your mindsets, expertise, and curiosity inspiring, especially as someone who truly understands the physical principles underlying the audio/technology we discuss but approximately 0% of its actual implementation in real world…

Do you find that as you’ve become very in demand mastering engineers you want to leave the technical stuff behind? Or think more deeply about where your time is best spent?

I ask because I’m a super intuitive-type when I master, but I like to devote very focused some time to rendering my tools to deep knowledge “available” in that intuitive flow. Probably on the @Rollmottle tip. But my science brain craves the technical understanding. 

There is only so much time in our lives and I’m curious if you think about how you time is best spent — mastering vs working on very technical things that I would argue offer no value to the actual artistic mastering process (minus having a good listen environment).

Trying to tie this back to the “makes a difference” vs “matters” thing…I think it’s great that there is so much enthusiasm for deep dives (ala @Zack Hames ) on here but I can’t help but think there would be little to no actionable info for most of us in what you two discuss! Sometimes I wonder if reading these threads gives me a false sense of accomplishment…like I now understand something that will never matter for me (and I could have just mastered a song instead)

As always, there is a balance and I’m trying to find my own…you two are just doing both the mastering and acoustics at such a high level I had to ask!

author: Rollmottle
content:
The Massive Passive is a beautiful EQ and does "the thing" exceptionally well...it's just not as versatile as I've come to need out of a box if I'm going out because it has inherent trade-offs that make it only partially useful when its in the signal path. I found myself only ever consistently using the top 2 bands because of the low-end mushiness. When I'm talking low-end mushiness, we are talking really subtle shades of gray, but at this stage can really make or break how a master hits, especially when thumpy kick drums are so critical to almost everything. It works a treat on drumless/acoustically oriented stuff, but that's more the exception of what flows across my desk than the rule. 

What I moved on to from the MP (the Gyraf G14S) gives me what I want when I'm going out without the inherent trade off in the low end. The ability to use it in either solid state or tube topology made it a no-brainer for me. It just does "the thing" cleaner and better than the MP. Where the MP is rich and dark, the Gyraf is rich and cleaner. I think at the end of the day, "tube" wasn't the thing I was looking for.

author: Rollmottle
content:
The things to check vary based on the requested deliverables. If you’re not really doing this regularly, for you, I'd make sure you’re asking up front if there are alts or files for physical releases that you need to account for. Cleans, instrumentals, acapellas, sequence, overlapping crossfades, metadata, PQ sheets, less lims, vinyl, etc. all may start to matter to finalizing something. And if you haven’t accounted for the deliverable and the time it takes to prep and QC in your rates, well you may be in for some pain.

Others may have some of these steps in different spots, but for me, it's roughly:

1. Print approved masters at native sample rate and bit depth.
1a. < Deprecate un-used versions>
1b.  <SRC/dither to any other sample rates and bit depth requested>
1c. <Assemble any physical deliverables>
2. Listen to every single file you’ve printed & check any data
3. Deliver

Sometimes the record is super consistent and it is "faster" in theory, but due dillgence is still needed on every song start finish, then if you get the track list or sequence and its a little complicated or they got high energy next to ballads next to high energy etc. You have to manage how that flows as well. SO I find singles are "easy" ...EP are little harder..... LP to get out the door, with each song reaching its potential while feeling cohesive often takes more "time". So no discounts. I will sometimes discount the total budget if the people are good, music is good and the budget is not my normal rate. SOMETIMES though I ask them to save up haha... because most can and most have rarely thought about that.

author: Berlin
content:
Prepare, QC after Export and Provide 1 WAV file per side, leave all transitions intact.
Prepare, QC after Export and Provide 1 PQ/Track Marker sheet per side - Use track start times on the side, not track lengths.. This is what the cutting engineer will use to make track markers when cutting.

The spaces between songs on the surface of the disc are visual markers only. Those will be created by the cutting engineer. Audio can run through the "spaces" as the groove is one long groove, start to finish.

author: Val ᶠʳ
content:
My Reaper workflow is to use the DDP marker formatting for every format's renders. (DDP, .wav, .mp3, even vinyl, etc...) 

Let's say you have your track markers formatted as : **#TITLE=songtitle|PERFORMER=artist|ISRC=666** etc., aside of the "!" marker at the beginning for the 2sec gap and the last "@" marker for the album metadata.
Your session is now ready for a DDP export.
Then, if you want to render .mp3 and/or .wav you have to use the wildcard : **$marker(#TITLE)[|]** in the file name entry, aside to other wildcards you'll need for folder structures etc. Also, the options :  "Bounds : All project markers" and "do not render files that are likely silent" are needed and will prevent rendering the empty first 2 sec marker.
To automatically include metadata in the files, you can use the same wildcards such as : **$marker(#TITLE)[|]** for Title,** $marker(PERFORMER)[|]** for Artist, **$marker(ISRC)[|]** for ISRC, etc etc...

With this method, you can, with one single workflow, render : DDPs, digital formats, and even vinyl, using additional regions. Once you have everything ready in render presets, it's super easy.
I recommend using the "WyattRice DDP editor" to easily edit the markers.
I've also made a script to automatically generate a .html "PQ sheet" file with timings, titles, ISRCs, etc, (both CD and Vinyl)

I hope it can help, English is not my native language, so feel free to ask for clarifications if needed.

author: Val ᶠʳ
content: I have a mastering project template with the grid set up in "Frames" with a frame rate of 75. It's basically for DDPs, but I generally do every other format with this grid setting to ensure CD compatibility in a single workflow.

author: masteredbyjack
content:
@Nomograph Mastering I’m sure you’ve looked into other options and I don’t know your workflow…but I’ve been using Streamdeck with a software called Keyboard Maestro and it basically functions as an assistant.

You can use the streamdeck to key cascades of tasks, and the keyboard maestro lets you direct where you want the mouse to click on the screen so you aren’t beholden to only key commands.

Of course it isn’t a cure-all, but as long as you aren’t running analog master passes which obviously need to be in real time, it can basically automate everything, name the files after they are bounced, etc. and you can set how long it waits in between tasks

Just a thought! It has been a real huge timer saver for me

I’m potentially missing the point here (there are probably reasons you mastering lot stay in RX rather than Tools), but… could you apply the workflow I use for declicking audio in PT to what you’re looking for above?

Eg - lead vocal will almost certainly have some clicks. I duplicate playlist (with suffix _Dclk), open up RX DeClick in Audiosuite and set to stun. Render it on the whole playlist indiscriminately while reading LWMR discord.

Flip back to the main playlist. Listen through with an egregious high shelf and a boatload of compression - comp up from the _Dclk playlist whenever you hit a click.

author: Zach Hughes
content:
I started mastering my first 12 song album yesterday. I've mastered other albums but 12 is the highest track count I've worked with on a project. I'm curious about other's approaches and work flows for mastering albums specifically.

I also have a more targeted question. I am wondering, in a world where most modern records take up all available headroom are relative track balance decisions (i.e. *I want the final chorus of track 3 to be the loudest perceived part of the entire album*) made at the input stage of the final limiter? Choosing less gain reduction via limiting or compression as well as distortion / saturation rather than turning a track down. Seems like a ratchet towards clipping, distortion, and lack of dynamic range and transient detail. Sure that's a whole can of worms but would be interested to discuss it. 🤘

author: masteredbyjack
content:
We did discuss a bit earlier but I’m not sure I understand your question — I think I read it as you looking into the trade off between turning down a more limited/compressed track (i.e to a dBFS level of like -.5 compared to where others are at) vs leaving the peak level and some more dynamics (which can also make a song sound quieter but in a different way)? 

IMO it’s just a gut feeling/listening game. Both approaches work but have different implications that have to be decided based on artistic intent.

But specifically for albums (and all mastering generally) working off intuition always works so much better for me. This also means you have to sort of practice outside of “game time” so the tools flow when in the moment. Able to work quicker so you keep the entire project in mind. Mastering is a game of trade offs both in songs themselves and between them.

Also IMO “cohesion” is totally overrated in mastering albums. I never care (or even know, honestly) as a listener if song 8 sounds cohesive with song 1. I just care that the arc of the album moves me

author: Zach Hughes
content: If track cohesion is out the window this doesn't really matter. However, if you care about the dynamics song to song on an album and the norm is that each track hits the same ceiling then it seems to me this would lead to needing to push the louder tracks harder and into a limiter potentially introducing more distortion and decreasing dynamic range. I guess I'm butting up against the norm of allowing all tracks to share the same output ceiling.

author: masteredbyjack
content:
Maybe I worded too strongly! Cohension matters, it's just that I find I care less about it than the feeling of the album if that makes sense. @Nomograph Mastering is way more experienced and knowledgeable than me on this.

I'd also push back against your assumption that every song has to have the same output ceiling. This may be "normal" but sometimes it's just not the move. Just did an album where one song wanted to be more compressed/limited. So we did that but just literally turned down the gain on the output so it fit better with another quieter (more dynamic, not output level) track before it to match the "loudness" of the two more closely.

Hard to give any other insight because so much of it is dependent on the actual songs you have, what the artist's vision is, how to serve that, etc. Dynamics/energy/loudness plays a big part in that!

author: hebakadry
content: Yeah definitely works in multi channel mode…you can use the spectral mode view to see all your files in your session on a spectral view and then the spectrum mouse tool to edit specific sections.  It’s def good for super quick cleanup when you don't want that choke.  I don’t normally work it in that way personally…I generally like to create an object for a section and then use the offline spectral repair to clean up the specific area because I just have more control in offline mode…also I can see where I did all my edits based on the splice if I need to repeat that on another version.  It’s not as deep as RX, but I still absolutely love it..so yeah great for efficiency.  I think I use it more than RX in a way because it all stays in the same environment and it’s super fast and easy.  You can still setup RX as an external tool in your object editor and stay in sequoia btw.  I have both RX and Spectralayers setup that way.  The only annoying thing is that you can’t have 2x ASIO running at the same instance which is very annoying. So I have to disable ASIO in my audio setup in Sequoia before I pull up RX..this is only if I want to STAY in the session.  Of course you can use it standalone as you know.  Anyways, it’s just a different workflow.

author: masteredbyjack
content:
Also question for @Gerhard Westphalen and everyone else:

How are you doing alt versions for EP and albums?

I’m in Wavelab, and I’d like to just line them all up after the current tracks (it is easy to apply spacing and fades to multiple clips at one to ensure the alts are exactly as the mains).

But in Wavelab when you do this it will encode each alt with a high track count number…ie for a 5 song album, the alts track number starts at 6. Granted this is only in the metadata but I still want to have that correct.

The other option is to replace clip with the alt version and then render it separately saved as a new montage file. I want a way to do it all in one project and restart the track numbering on each alt version.

Does anyone know if that’s possible, or just how are you handling it?

I ask because I do know how to do it multiple ways but I’d like to be more efficient for revisions, etc…say if someone wants to change a fade I’m not going through 4 montages to get all the alts too

author: masteredbyjack
content:
I did actually watch that (but I forgot until you mentioned it sorry). But I feel like my way is actually still more efficient…I have an AppleScript that names everything for me, etc but Wavelab just can’t reset the track numbers…

The names aren’t the problem it’s the track number encoded in the metadata…does Nuendo solve this?

I’m sure this doesn’t matter in the real world but this is a nerd out place so just curious.

And I’ve been seeing metadata creep into more and more things…my default finder “spacebar” play on Mac now displays artist and album info

author: masteredbyjack
content: I was wrong, your Nuendo workflow does almost exactly what I want minus the “full mix” file rename (or having to bounce separately)…but it’s certainly efficient enough that it’s splitting hairs. Gave me some good ideas. Thank you!!

They had another studio also master the album (they hired me because that studio didn’t have availability but ended up having availability). Completely crushed, bottom end gone etc. They came back to me and said they liked what the other studio did but didn’t like certain things which the other studio couldn’t fix (too much distortion and compression…) so they wanted me to do something along those lines but better… was a complete mess and after a long (and productive) meeting to discuss the direction they wanted for the next revision they emailed saying they didn’t want another revision from me and wouldn’t be paying for the album (which at that point I had mastered from scratch 3 times)

author: masteredbyjack
content:
When you are referring to this, do you QC just the literal downsample?

In my workflow I QC on import…so I’d catch any odd stuff, clicks, whatever (in all the alts too). Then of course the finals that go out, the highest res render (changes depending on project like you stated).

But just a downsample to 4416 (or whatever) you even QC? What could go wrong there? (I’ve tested RX pretty extensively and I’ve never seen it add an error just downsampling minus a potential over here or there depending…I do account for potential overs from the downsampling and make sure there aren’t any…etc)

Open to being wrong about this, but haven’t had any problems so far (caveat with my experience is minimal compared to you and Gerhard, Rollmottle, etc)

author: masteredbyjack
content:
Thanks for response, was honestly just curious! I’m not willing to roll the dice, and the certainty is a big part of what we provide 

but I’m also always looking to see if I can make more foolproof processes and spend as much time doing creative decision making, rather than something that’s redundant for no reason.

I don’t think this is that, but it’s something that’s top of my mind (for instance in my workflow I’m never actually copying or naming files usually, and if I am there is only one point of failure which is known. And yes I verify that it all goes as should, but there is less chance of problems)

author: omarakrouche
content: On this topic-- I'm curious how you guys do your spacing. Do you do it in the same session as the mastering? Sorry if this has already been asked a milli times

author: masteredbyjack
content:
Yep same session! Wavelab for me, montage. Some caveats apply, like if you are doing a seamless transition I find it useful to print to a new montage file to avoid any chance of an odd click or pop across the track transition, the new montage print seems to solve that (obviously always have to QC) but that's the only time I do that

Also have to caveat this with I am quite new, but I've done quite a few album/EP projects and the spacing in the same file seems very much the right move for me (my plugin use is pretty minimal so rendering the files isn't much of a lift on the back end when it's ready to go)

And circling back to not having the tracklist -- very common for me, not a big deal, your workflow should have a way to handle it without it being a problem in today's day and age. But I will certainly go back and look at spacing/volume in the intro/outros for sure with the tracklist. Have had projects go out and they didn't provide a tracklist, last second decision and it was totally fine

author: cian riordan
content: I may not have your reps, but I have yet to have an album come across my desk that I prep for vinyl that doesn’t sound better with 5 dB less limiting. I get that our line of work is constantly trying to shovel shit rolling down the hill at us, but I think there’s more nuance than “modern records are loud and need to stay loud otherwise they fall apart.” Vinyl isn’t a medium that was designed with -7 or -9 LUFS in mind… and I have yet to hear a vinyl pressing cut in this contemporary fashion that doesn’t sound like a pile of assholes. I have lots of time for serving the client and the project, being a team player and getting things across the line.. but that’s usually the reality of the business... not what’s best for the Sonics. I think vinyl has the opportunity to sound amazing but modern mixing AND mastering techniques are often getting in the way of that.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content:
Definitely fair. Let me flesh it out a little. Let’s imagine we have a competent and engaged team of Artist, Producer and Mixer….

Artist creates, takes it so far and then needs the objectivity and skill of a Producer to finish the arranging and production. At that stage we have a tired team very close to the work …

In steps the mixer with a fresh perspective and skillset, they go hard on an album’s worth of material building mixes one atom at a time. By the end of the mix process we ideally would have a rejuvenated Artist and Producer who can step back and hear the whole work in a way the mixer may not be able to … 

Then to mastering - another completely fresh take. To me depending on the time gap the mixer is often just tapped out at this stage and the Artist or producer may have more to give

author: Rob Domos
content:
Best practices question: 

I sent out a bunch of finished, approved, dithered mixes to a client and then they told me the song order sequence and wanted me to tighten up the transitions, so I loaded those dithered mixes up and trimmed tops and tails. I imagine since I didn’t add any processing (other than one imperceptible fade) and I already randomized the bottom bit in the previous project that I should be good to export and ship as is, but are there any reasons why it would have been functionally better to have done tops and tails on the undithered file and applied dithering afterwards?

author: masteredbyjack
content:
From my understanding and tests, yes if it is imported in a DAW and changed at all, we are now in 32 or 64 bit land. Will you hear this difference? Most likely no like Ruairi said, it would have to be a very specific case.

Over here I always dither after export in RX, so it solves that issue. And for an album I’ll print the whole thing to a separate montage so if it’s just spacing or whatever that needs to change, it’s easy enough and no re-rendering of plugins is necessary (and Wavelab seems to handle seamless transitions better this way)

I’ve seen a fair amount of non-limited mixes that I find out are truncated to 24 bit depth — any over zeros that a limiter was catching go to zero — and even then it usually doesn’t really sound horrible since it’s often a very fast transient peak. But something to be aware of

author: aidanthillmann
content:
Hi, I’m not a mastering engineer but I did a sort of mastering experiment recently:

I was watching the Mix with the Masters videos with Randy Merrill and Idania Valencia, and I noticed that they were using plain old input gain before their limiter to push it instead of increasing the threshold of the limiter itself, so their limiter thresholds/gains were at 0. I thought maybe they knew something I didn’t.

So I tried it. I put a gain plugin before my limiter and pushed the limiter with it. The results? It sounds awful. All the punch and width is gone. Change back to using the limiter’s threshold, sounds great.

Any technical reason for this? I was using the Kilohearts Gain plugin in to Ozone Maximizer, but I would be hard pressed if it was one of those plugins at fault. Maybe the threshold of the limiter has an internal signal flow that changes its behavior as opposed to gain coming in to it or something? Maybe this workflow makes better sense in Sequoia for the Sterling engineers for some reason?

author: masteredbyjack
content: I actually believe @cian riordan mentioned here before that there IS something different about how the Ozone maximizer reacts to pushing gain into it with threshold at 0 vs using the input gain. For my workflow, when I use it I'm pushing into it with the input gain, so I'd have to do some tests. But for other limiters (limitless, Pro L2), I haven't noticed a big difference between what you're suggesting -- very open to being wrong about that though!

author: Edsel Holden
content:
Is the accepted wisdom here that Spotify normalizes off of one single LUFSi for an album? (All the songs together, this is what I understood)

Audio Accountibility (Dale's thing) dropped a live saying that he has been told by the powers that be that is incorrect - and it actually normalizes off the loudest song on the album. Which is well, news to me. 

I often work on records that have very loud moments and very small moments, it is a bummer to realize that is lowering their normalized volume (when streaming form the album).

Anyway, this blew my mind. Normalization sucks.

author: Edsel Holden
content: I think this would change my approach to albums that have very small moments. I think , if this is really true, having a more consistent volume throughout an album will make the whole album stream louder... which def robs some of the dynanmic feeling.

author: Rollmottle
content: Doing it this way maintains the integrity of the relationships of the relative volumes of songs within an album context vs. normalizing it another way, no? This seems like the right way to do it and I thought where there was already gravity around approaching album normalization like this, instead of normalizing an album like playlists.

author: Berlin
content: Most interesting note of his video is: If you pull a quiet track from an album, and then add it to a stand alone playlist, apparently it will then stream at -14 on its own.

author: masteredbyjack
content:
From my understanding it's:

1. Album is given an integrated LUFS score as a whole, and taken down (or turned up) according to the integrated score

2. Album is turned down or up according to the LUFS score of ONLY the loudest song on an album

Dale says what's happening is #2 on Spotify

From what I've seen with what I've been releasing, #1 is happening on Apple (but maybe it changed)

author: Edsel Holden
content:
Yes - and this is why having a SUPER loud song and SUPER quiet one on the same album is... actually lowering normalized volume for whole record (when played from the record).

So, maybe having a more consistent volume throughout is worth it in 2024.

author: masteredbyjack
content:
Alright I'm back with another question for the hive mind:

Finishing up an EP today we've been slow-dripping for awhile. First song we did had big drums, tons of low, measures louder (-8.4 LUFS). Mastered and approved before the rest of them came this way. Rest of the songs are sparse, open, beautiful. But accordingly meausre much lower (loudest is -11 LUFS). 

So with the new info Dale posted the other day re: how Spotify is normalizing levels, I thought let's just turn down the louder one a little to see how it fits (it's fine), maybe that can buy us a db or whatever for the other songs when they normalize to the loudest song as long as the creative intent is preserved (it is). And that's cool. But actually a better result IMO was to just ease up on the loudness of the first song (at -8.4 LUFS), it makes more sense in the project being a bit more dynamic rather than having the dense one be pulled down.

Question is: will this cause the single version to be replaced by the new album one when going to distro?

I've had masters that we replaced before with a lowered ceiling in projects and all was fine, but the actual master was exactly the same minus the ceiling, so in a single context it would normalize the same. I know to keep exact length to ms, etc etc. 

But the new info Dale posted makes me rethink how to handle this in albums (on Spotify -- on Apple is doesn't seem to be doing that?)

New to the discord here but just read through the ADM chat and have an interesting follow up.

I am certified to provide ADM. About a year ago I noticed that a label I work with was submitting my non-ADM files to Apple as ADM and still getting certified. I asked the label to use the ADM files in the future as I didnt want to risk my accreditation. They responded that nothing had been flagged by distribution nor by Apple but they would do so moving forward.

Flash forward to this year - I noticed that some ADM files from other engineers had overs, not just clipping but significant overs, check the newest Olivia Rodrigo album. According to the aforementioned document, definitely not to spec hahah.

Flash forward from there to about a month ago, I submitted my standard formats to another label I work with including standard streaming WAV as well as an ADM file. Through chatting with their distribution team it came to light that at the distro end of things they could only upload 1 file (the ADM) and this file would be delivered to each DSP in the specs they can receive, which I found very interesting since the ADM file is occasionally different than the other streaming WAVs.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content:
For gapless I print a single file with all processing

Then find a zero crossing and split into 2 separate tracks, I don’t do a little fade in or out

Re checking if it worked, iTunes is not a reliable indicator of anything ever, it’s a dead product now

You need to test several things to QC properly, all of these will bite you in the ass at some point

1) Does the end of the first track (from the split file) play cleanly on it’s own

2) Does the second track play cleanly (the start) on its own?

If so great. Now the big caveat 

Streaming services serve up many different types of files - OGG, AAC, MP3, FLAC and ALAC. From memory AAC and MP3 both add small amounts of silence at the start of file when you compress the file, this is done automatically during the data compression (and silence added can even vary depending on codec used and sample rate)

This means that what was a seamless transition between your spliced files will now have a gap, sometimes that creates an audible disturbance, sometimes not

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: It means that what is a nice seamless transition locally can go wrong in certain streaming services sometimes, and it’s hard to predict. It can be fine on Spotify mobile but not on desktop because of the different codecs served

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: The silence induced will not be a problem on some pop stuff. But can Bork a piano transition like you wouldn’t believe

But the Master WAVs and DDPs are great.. Hit or miss elsewhere. But More often than not it works.

author: Nick Stetina
content:
+ @Rollmottle , you know what, poor word choice on my part by saying “undoing”, haha. What I really meant was in the event of a revision request. 

For example, I worked on a song this week with a jazz quartet instrumentation and a singer with a bit of a lisp. Super dynamic mix, the upright bass had a lot of wild moments that needed to be reigned in. Always gonna follow my gut on the to first pass, but also recognize the singer’s potential sensitivity to how their lisp comes across on the recording. I just opted to focus on the instrumentals on the first pass in RX, save the file, duplicate it, then work from that and focus on vocals. They approved on the first pass, but if I had to go back to the drawing board on the vocals, for example, I did not want to have to go through every note plucked on the upright bass again and would be thankful to have that ‘RX_INST’ file on hand.

Which I guess brings up another workflow question: are you splitting focus when in RX and doing multiple passes, or just play through once addressing whatever it is you hear as you go?

author: nachomaquieira
content: Hi everyone! Today I thought I’d write here to ask how you approach mastering an album that you've mixed yourself. Sometimes I work on albums where the mixes are done in a very short time, and other times it takes longer, so the focus changes over time (which is totally natural). Right now, what I’m doing is setting up a mastering session with all the latest mixes (with limiting applied), doing the track list, and listening to the differences between them—things like timbre, balance, loudness, etc. I make notes of what I hear, then go back to the mix sessions to make small tweaks. After that, I export everything without the final clipping/limiting on the tracks, so I can apply those in the final mastering session and then master the album. Anyone with a different approach is more than welcome to share, as right now I’m wrapping up a lot of albums I’ve worked on throughout the year, and I want to stay as sharp as possible to give them a proper finish.

author: Paris Lee
content:
@Stefan 
I don’t audition different converters on every track. That would drive me insane. 
For an album that would be more of a thing…but I’ll be honest I’ll just use one converter for a while across some projects and then I’ll switch to the other one arbitrarily for a while…

(I have a Crane Song Interstellar and a Lavry Savitr
Both great All Rounders that have proven legacies  and hard to get a bad sound out of…)

I’m not a big believer that the converter is the ‘barrier’ to delivering your best work. If you’re in a room where you’re hearing what’s happening clearly, you can work. Now we all have our preferences on that ‘last 5 percent’ of sonics, which influences your decision, but if I can hear the eq and get a cohesive tight image and strong center, it doesn’t matter, I’m fine. All of that is Much more important. 

These converters are all so fucking good now. I think 15 years ago which one you had was more of a heated discussion. 

Just don’t feel the need to go off the reservation on the ones you’ve seen in the top guys racks over the years, and…DONT BUT SOME VINTAGE THING THAT COULD BREAK ON YOU!!! Get something new that’s supported. 

Maybe I over answered haha. Coffee ya know

author: Ted Whitten Media
content: A little update to an earlier discussion about gapless playback on Spotify. I was able to actually get in touch with someone who confirmed that both their OGG and AAC streams have gapless capability, and, more importantly, they also confirmed that gapless is simply designed to remove the silence added by the encoding process and will not touch anything in the original master. So at least timing wise, listening to an album with gapless playback enabled should exactly match the master.

author: Elaine Rasnake
content:
Generally when I've had to master files for someone to press to vinyl, I will take the limiter off and create  designated A side / B Side files along with a PQ sheet of all of the start/stop times, album order, and things like that via HOFA DDP Maker.
I leave all of the high end low end adjustments to the pressing engineer since they will know best what needs to be adjusted, if at all. 

I know of some folks who also just send the limited "digital distro" files but I prefer to give a more dynamic version and the pressing engineer can adjust it.

Usually an artist will go through test pressings and if there are issues, usually (or at least ideally) the pressing engineer, the artist, and the mastering engineer are all communicating about things and next steps

author: hebakadry
content: Ultimately it’s the material itself that should be considered not like a rule of thumb thing that works for every single album.  Like a hot dance/techno record with no vocals will cut really beautifully with all the limiting intact…if anything, the tracing playback distortion will bring back some harmonics lost and make some HH or snares crunch in a really pleasing way.  On a really congested rock record with very low crest factor and really upfront vocals, pulling back limiting does actually help and gives a little bit of head room to not expose as many artefacts on playback.

author: bobby k
content: i think to shed light on why this crossed my mind, i always swing for a finished sounding record and play ball without assuming the artist even plans to have it mastered (if it's a single at least - if it's an album we def get talking about that earlier). mixing for me is definitely a relationship between the individual sources and the macro processing and i cannot imagine doing the process without that back n forth. but it did cross my mind as a potential avenue of collaboration between two people with lots of trust. i saw a wee bit under the hood with Nathan Dantzler and Julian Benetta on the COIN album in 2022 just by virtue of hanging  with nathan - I believe they were passing him unfinished mixes and demos, getting his input and collaborating on the mix buss decisions along the way as they were still recording, looong before he actually "mastered it". which seemed like a rare but neat process to witness and is thoroughly different than what i think the general response was here (the "please save this" experience). and made me wonder if that "consulting" part of the process  is considered a branch of mastering, or something else entirely. cheers!

author: Ted Whitten Media
content:
When doing revisions, does anyone save a whole new project file with a version number appended to the end? Wondering if that might help me stay more organized. Currently working on an album where the client wanted to go back to V1 for release, and I swear I kept track of every move I'd made to get to v2, but for some reason I just couldn't get it to sound exactly like V1 again. It's no problem on their end because they just used the file I'd rendered and uploaded to Samply. But now I have a clip in my montage that doesn't match the released version, which I don't like. I ended up dropping the master on a reference track instead.

I think this issue was partially caused because I tend to send an initial rough master too early in the process and they get demo-itis. For some reason I've always wanted to send clients an initial rough master after I've done the quick "from the gut" broad strokes, but before I've totally nailed down the nitty gritty stuff, to see if they like the direction I'm headed. And all too often they end up liking the first version.

Or maybe I'm just overthinking v2 and making it worse on a regular basis? I dunno... 😂

author: Rob Domos
content:
Let’s say you have a vocal and an instrumental that are both very “unbalanced” in a traditional sense frequency response wise in opposite directions. 

If you make the vocal feel good and human, the overall balance of the record will be very lumpy, and if you make the overall balance of the record sit in a place that feels balanced, the vocal will feel cheap and janky.

I don’t think there’s going to be any hard and fast rules because every record is different and navigating those vibe tradeoffs in relationship to the intention of the music is a part of the job, but I’m curious if anyone has any insights, philosophical or otherwise for this somewhat common occurrence. (Doesn’t have to be about the vocal but it is for me on this album)

author: masteredbyjack
content: This. In the sense that relative differences in levels on albums are kept

author: masteredbyjack
content: Albums get turned down based on their loudest song

author: masteredbyjack
content:
So if something measures -9lufs integrated, on its own it gets turned down 5 db

If it’s on an album and the loudest song is -7.5 integrated, it will play back 6.5db quieter when played from the album

author: Halliemmelton
content:
I have a big question and maybe there would be a better “general” thread for it but would love anyone’s insight.

I just remastered an album for an artist—not gonna say who mastered it the first time, the masters aren’t bad and the mastering house has a great reputation—but the new masters are without a doubt more engaging and bring the intent of the record forward a lot more. I think it’s in part because have a more personal relationship with the artist and could dig in harder knowing their intentions.

I’ll lead with—I’m biased af. Not because of my masters or anything, just because of my relationship with the artist and how I want them to do well. 

The single I mastered for the artist did really well streaming, and this previous (imho really amazing, again I’m biased) record had kinda flopped—def didn’t get the attention it deserved, and it got zero playlisting—I’m talking less thank 25k streams compared to the single’s 300k streams. 

I really love the record and do not think it got the chance it deserved. 

The artist loves the new masters, and we’re now chatting about resubmitting these new masters—if we swap out, it feels like there’s zero chance to reconsider playlisting? In theory I know playlisting may not make a difference, but the single’s stream counts make us feel like it’s important enough to consider. The album was released in 2022, so re-releasing it as a different version is definitely an option as well—but curious if any of you have any experience in remasters/rereleases etc and have any opinions or advice on different ways this could be handled!

author: Jasper Boogaard
content:
I think the chance for playlisting here would be a lot higher if there’s a new team/label behind it pushing it to streaming services’ editorial teams. In my experience the label’s PR team is still very important in playlisting and if the remaster gets a new push from a new label that might help a lot.  

if they do a smart repackaging as a deluxe remastered album, maybe add a live version or bonus track, this might help too. They will definitely get another push in the Spotify Release Radar which is a good source of new streams.

author: Halliemmelton
content:
Thanks for your input!

Not reaaaally trying to push it as a whole new release—he’s got another ep that’s almost ready for mastering that he’s looking to release top of the year, so just want to swap these files out in the next month or so. I think the “playlists” we’d submit to are mostly editorial anyway, not fully trying to release it as new songs—just hoped to garner some level of “here, listen again, it’s better now” and use the opportunity to verbally/manually promote it again.

author: miguel @ knurlmastering
content:
Reaper is the best DAW for mastering when you look at its feature set, audio capabilities, and overall flexibility.

The two issues that often get confused are the learning curve and the customization options. The real challenge is shaping Reaper to fit your workflow and that’s what I mean by learning curve. But once that’s done, you’re not stuck endlessly tweaking, it’s actually the other way around. It becomes streamlined, efficient, and allows you to focus entirely on mastering music instead of fighting with the software.

In the end, it comes down to whether you’re willing to invest the time and patience to make it work for you. It’s perfectly valid if you’d rather not go through that process but if you do, you’ll likely find that Reaper is unmatched for mastering.

author: Berlin
content:
If you want you can implement 2x oversampling to help mitigate ISP a little, but if you wanted a little more control, you can upsample and work at that high sample rate. Export at that higher sample rate, and 32bit float.

SRC and Dither using RX for your various formats.

Reassemble in your DAW for each program. i.e. Main Master, DDP, or Vinyl Premaster.

Find a workflow that works for
you.

Lots of folks don’t worry about these things and just export, listen and party. 🎉

author: Bryan DiMaio
content: Vocalign Pro with ARA could also potentially speed things up but I've always done it in AudioSuite. Just something to look at in case it can fit into your workflow

author: Bryan DiMaio
content:
Additionally, I know some artists love to comp thoroughly after the fact but it could be helpful (and idk your current workflow so you may already do this) to go one of two routes:
1. color code any specific takes that may be keepers outright
2. try to be as intentional as possible while tracking so you're building the comp as you go and you know when you get "the take"

Most of the vocals I track are comped, edited, and aligned on the fly while tracking. It took me years of practice to be able to do all that while still paying attention to the current take that's being sung but I find artists love the speed they can see their song come together

author: Bryan DiMaio
content: Yeah I think loop recording sections is gonna be your friend here, the less time wasted on the back and forth of "let's do that section again" for 20+ throwaway takes might save everyone involved some valuable time. Def talk about it with him though to see if he's comfortable with that workflow
